subject: Re: Order of multiple @Before methods in one class
msgSnippet: Hello, Robin! Alternative way will be to use inheritance. It will be something like this. public class Base { @Before public void setUp(){ ... } @After public
messageBody:
Hello, Robin!
Alternative way will be to use inheritance. It will be something like
this.

public class Base {
@Before
public void setUp(){
...
}

@After
public void tearDown(){
...
}
}

public class MyTest extends Base {
@Before
public void setUp(){
...
}

@After
public void tearDown(){
...
}
}



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kentb" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Robin,
>
> There is no defined order to the execution of Before and After
methods. If
> you have two bits of setup that are temporally coupled, the most
direct way
> I can think of to express that coupling is to put them in the same
Before:
>
> @Before public void setup() {
> firstBit();
> dependentSecondBit();
> }
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>
> _____
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> Robin de Silva Jayasinghe
> Sent: Monday, August 04, 2008 4:58 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Order of multiple @Before methods in one class
>
>
>
> Hi List!
>
> Today I asked myself whether there is a given order if I decorate
> multiple methods in one class with @Before or @After. All of the
> methods are executed but I have no idea how JUnit determines the
> execution order. I changed the ordering of the methods in the source
> code as well as the name of the methods. Both with no effect on the
> ordering. Is there any defined order or shall I rely on the assumption
> that the order is undefined?
>
> Best Regards,
> Robin
>
>
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
